rbw.simulation package¶

High-level interface for rigid body physics using pybullet.

Submodules¶

rbw.simulation.interface module¶

A collection of functions interfacing with pybullet simulations

Implemented as functions rather than classes to facilitate cross-language support.

rbw.simulation.interface.apply_state(sim_map, key_order, state)[source]¶

Applies a state matrix to each object reported

The expected dimensions of state are obsxSTATE where obs is the number of objects (in order) and STATE is the tuple representing the dimensions of the component.

Parameters

  • object_ids – A list of ids corresponding objects in state

  • state – A tuple of position, rotation, angular velocity and linear velocity for each object.

rbw.simulation.interface.clear_client(cid)[source]¶

Clean up connection if not already done.

rbw.simulation.interface.clear_sim(sim_map)[source]¶

Clean up connection if not already done.

rbw.simulation.interface.init_client(debug=False, **kwargs)[source]¶

” Returns an initialized pybullet client.

rbw.simulation.interface.init_sim(sim, data, cid)[source]¶

Loads a world into a client and returns an sim map

Parameters

  • sim – A Sim class

  • data – json-serialized scene data to be parsed by sim

  • cid – The client id to using for sim

rbw.simulation.interface.run_full_trace(sim_map, T=1.0, fps=60, time_scale=1.0, debug=False)[source]¶

Runs pybullet on on given scene Frames per second are fixed at 60 If no objects are given, then the top keys of serialized_scene are used.

Parameters

  • data – Dict representing scene

  • objs,optional – Order of objects to report.

  • T – The duration in seconds to simulate

  • fps – The rate at which to report state

  • time_scale – The time scale factor

  • debug – Whether to run with debug visualization

rbw.simulation.interface.run_mc_trace(sim_map, state=None, fps=60, time_scale=1.0)[source]¶
rbw.simulation.interface.step_trace(client, sim, dur, time_step=240, fps=60, time_scale=1.0, state=None, debug=False, ret_col=True)[source]¶

Obtains sim state from simulation.

Currently returns the position of each rigid body. The total duration is equal to frames / fps

Parameters

  • dur (float) – The amount of time in seconds to simulate

  • objects ([str]) – List of strings of objects to report

  • time_step (int, optional) – Number of physics steps per second

  • fps (int, optional) – Number of frames to report per second.

rbw.simulation.interface.update_world(sim_map, new_world)[source]¶

Updates the world’s physical parameters

Parameters

  • client – Pybullet client id

  • object_map – The object name -> object id dict

New_world

A serialized scene containing new physical properties

rbw.simulation.ramp_sim module¶

class rbw.simulation.ramp_sim.RampSim(scene_json, client)[source]¶

Bases: rbw.simulation.sim.Sim

Handles physics for ramp worlds.

Defines a method make_table to describe a table top with 3 edge boundaries (+x, +y, -y)

property client¶

The pybullet client key

make_table(params)[source]¶
property world¶

A Dict containing references to loaded objects
